reporting-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

title.narrative: Regional Workshop on Prevention and Control of Neglected Zoonoses in Asia

description.narrative: Support the science and practice of food, feed, and fiber production (including forestry, wildlife, fisheries, aquaculture and floriculture) and its relationships to natural resources, processing, marketing, distribution, utilization (including nutrition), and trade.

This award strives to support the science and practice of food, feed, and fiber production (including forestry, wildlife, fisheries, aquaculture and floriculture) and its relationships to natural resources, processing, marketing, distribution, utilization (including nutrition), and trade. In addition, this award On July 15-16, 2015, APHIS, in collaboration with World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) Regional Representation for Asia and the Pacific and the United Nation's Food and Agriculture Organization’s Animal Production and Health Commission for Asia and the Pacific (APHCA), organized a Regional Workshop on Prevention and Control of Neglected Zoonosis’ in Asia’ from July 15-16, 2015 in Obihiro, Japan. The objectives of this workshop were to provide the participants with updates on the situation and the burden of neglected zoonosis in Asia and overview of relevant OIE standards in controlling neglected zoonosis. APHIS shared the expense of the workshop by supporting the logistics. The objectives of this workshop were to provide the participants with: 1) updates on the situation and the burden of neglected zoonosis in Asia. 2) Provide an overview of relevant OIE standards in controlling those diseases. 3) Identify opportunities to share experiences and learn from each other, and 4) Gain support from international and regional organizations to national control programs addressing neglected zoonosis, particularly brucellosis. Through these activities, it was recognized that not much research had been conducted in the region on salmonellosis, brucellosis, tuberculosis and food-borne parasites, which are so called Neglected Zoonosis.
